page.title: 11A SHORT HISTORY OF CULROSS 3
page.content: Culross also became well-known for its baking girdles and in l599 James VI granted the Culross smiths a monopoly for making them. It was to last l5Oyrs. In l575 Sir George Bruce, the most important person in the history of Culross, took over Culross colliery. He made Culross so prosperous it was made a Royal Burgh and he built himself a house so grand it was dubbed "The Palace". In l625 a great storm destroyed the under-sea mine workings and shortly after, Sir George died. Mining died out and with it salt-panning. Carron,across the Forth, produced cheaper cast-iron girdles.The people of Culross tried other professions, without success. The village fell on hard times. In a way this was the secret of Culross's success today. They couldn't afford new houses and wider streets.
